Receiving the same block multiple times doesn't seem correctly handled.

nodes.bodyText:
listener is only for testing?
if thats the case, I would spec a diff constructor adding the listener, and a comment that its only for testing.
this allow us to avoid a "null" in RskContext construction and a clear knowledge that its not used in real scenario.
Done. Basically that listener is just an interface, so potentially can be used anywhere

Shouldn't we validate header and block, before preprocessing?
This is a more open/complex question.
The issue that i see, is that if block header (e.g.) is invalid, we'll be trying to get parents when not necessary.

preprocessing basically does simple checks before block processing like distance to the best block. More importantly it checks if a parent block has already been gotten. Without parent we cannot validate block or start its processing.

I think we should decouple that logic (maybe have a BlockBasicValidator which validates genesis, header and block), then preprocess and finally run parents validation. For me it doesn't make sense to preprocess a block with invalid header
I didn't follow all the discussion, but I think we should do all the validations that NOT involves access to disk or memory caches, FIRST.
No limit queue could bring issues?

I'd prefer not to have any upper limit. This queue is a temporary storage for blocks to be processed in a separate thread, so this shouldn't be huge in terms of size. Most of the time its size should be close to zero.
you could extract this to a method, to make it more readable.
Done
this could be extracted outside the log line, to make it more readable.
Done
make sense to add block hash/number?
Done
"preprocess" is executed twice? first time when you put in the queue and this is the second time when you actually process it?
Yes
We could leave this until the next step. It's too soon to take care of this case.
be careful here... if it happens to fail, it won't stop. Is there anyway to put a timeout here?
This is a test. But any way added a timeout for tests
why wait time so high?
set to to 60 secs
why dont you save the last result and ask only for the last one outside the loop?
it's actually being saved in blockToWait and processed outside the loop. Or did I get you wrong?
I liked these before/after, cant we do sthg similar with the other test class?
Do you mean AsyncNodeBlockProcessorTest class? In this class AsyncNodeBlockProcessor is constructed differently for every test. Or did you mean something else?

The PoW rule should be validated before this.
It would be easy to DoS the nodes in the current state: RSKIP92 allows the creation of a block with the same hash but with invalid PoW, and the current code would allow it to reach the store actually forcing the valid block to be rejected.

@donequis, I've separated block validation onto two stages. Block header validation now happens before store.hasBlock(block), and it includes PoW and block timestamp validation rules. Validation of the block itself and its parent happens later on (as it was before). Let me know about your thoughts.
Why not to delegate this logic to a block processor getter? Or is there a situation when even having fast block propagation enable, we should need the direct block processor instead of async one?
done
Can we default to false for this validators? There's no need to relay a genesis block
